sub_title: PhD Candidate at Eindhoven University of Technology
summary:
I am passionate about sustainability, particularly about sustainable development in the global south. The environmental, economic, and social effects of global trade as well as the teleconnections between the global north and south resulting from globalised trade are currently at the focus of my research. With my research I aim to advance our understanding of un/sustainable developments ranging across time and space to eventually better govern global connections.
Besides my PhD research I am passionate about the issue of reducing food waste and changing western food systems.

awards.title: Nomination for UM Student Award
awards.description:
The UM Student Award is issued to students who stand out due to their academic performance and exceptional contribution to Maastricht University. Besides a large financial reward, students' pictures are put up in the UM student hall of fame. 
My friend and me were nominated for the award due to our exceptional contribution with Foodsharing Maastricht.  We were one of six nominees and did not win the price in the end. However, it was a great honour to even be nominated  and to be cherished by the UM community during the opening ceremony of the academic year.

awards.title: MaRBLe Bachelor's Honours Programme
awards.description:
Maastricht Research Based Learning, MaRBLe for short, is UM’s excellence programme for talented and motivated 3rd year bachelor students. MaRBLe brings multidisciplinary scientific research to the bachelor phase. Parallel to my BA thesis I worked on the broader research project with the topic "democracy and resentment: why are so many people angry today?". Within this topic frame I specialised on a comparative framing analysis between the German left wing movement surrounding the Hambacher Forest and the German right wing movement PEGIDA.
MaRBLe was a great experience for me and enabled me to do larger scale research on a highly independent basis, followed by my first publication.

awards.title: UM Student Idea Competition
awards.description:
The UM student idea award is given to students with exceptional ideas, to enable them to put their idea into practice. 
My best friend and me applied for the award in 2017 and ended up wining it. The idea we applied with was Foodsharing Maastricht. The general concept of Foodsharing is commonly know in Germany and involves the saving of expired food, or goods that do not look good enough to be sold anymore. Such goods are picked up from supermarkets, hotels, bakeries etc. and redistributed to society for free. The main objective of this is the reduction of food waste in society.
With this idea we won the price and founded the initiative shortly after. It has been running and growing successfully ever since.

profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate

profile_positions.description:
My best friend and I founded Foodsharing in January 2017, after we won the student idea competition at Maastricht University. The general concept of Foodsharing is commonly known in my home country Germany, but the movement is only now starting in the Netherlands so that we were one of the first initiatives. The main objective is to fight food waste by collecting food from shops, hotels, restaurants etc. that would otherwise be thrown away. With a team of volunteers we pick up food around 30 times per week to redistribute it for free.
I have been leading this project parallel to my Bachelor and Master studies. Hereby, my tasks include: social media (facebook), coordination of a team of around 30 volunteers, negotiating deals and contracts with shops, external & internal communication, leading team meetings, and recruitment of new volunteers every semester.  Besides, quite frequently we organised events, information markets, or I hold presentations informing people about the challenge of food waste and how to avoid it in the future. 
 
Leading Foodsharing shaped me and made me grow immensely as a person. It continuously challenged me and taught me a lot about leadership, time management and communication with my team and external partners.

profile_positions.company: Education and Training for Sustainable Agriculture and Nutrition in East Africa (EaTSANE)
profile_positions.description:
I conducted my Master thesis research for the KIT Tropical Institute of the Netherlands and their "Education and Training for Sustainable Agriculture and Nutrition in East Africa" (EaTSANE) programme. The tropic of my research was "Post harvest food loss and waste in the nutritional value chain of nightshade and bush beans in Uganda". 
For this purpose I conducted a one month field research in Uganda, including interviews and focus group discussions with around 90 local farmers, traders and consumers.  This enabled me to study amounts and causes of economic, physical and nutritional losses from harvest until consumption and ti formulate recommendations for potential improvements.
profile_positions.title: Researcher

profile_positions.description:
PREMIUM is an extracurricular excellence programme for talented Master students,
aiming to prepare soon-to-be-graduating students for the fast-approaching job market.
Thereby, PREMIUM attempts to bridge the gap between study and career. Participating
students complete a project for a client in interdisciplinary teams, attend workshops, and work
on personal professional development in an individual competence coaching trajectory.
I was part of a student consultant team working for the Provincial Government of Limburg. The aim of this project was to give the government advice on how to increase participation in the financial scheme Duurzaam Thuis, which supports house owners in conducting sustainable housing renovations.
Working as a consultant for the government is a great opportunity and has given me great insights into to the internal workings of the Dutch energy transition. Besides, the team work, coaching, and variety of workshops strongly supported my personal development and taught me a lot about myself.

The International Student Network (ISN) is part of the Europe wide Erasmus Student Network (ESN). It is the biggest student organisation in Europe and aims at supporting exchangers to settle in, feel at home, and have a good Erasmus experience. At the beginning I was part of the social committee and in charge of organising social events on the weekly basis. Later on I joined the partnership committee, which deals with potential ISN partners in Maastricht. This includes negotiations with shops, restaurants etc. to get deals and discounts for ESN card members.
